message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiographic findings and photomicrograph suggest osteosarcoma. Moth-eaten appearance and wide transition zone indicate the lesion has invaded the cortical bone. Multiple myeloma usually presents with diffuse osteoporosis, whereas chondrosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma do not usually cause a periosteal reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray findings and photomicrograph suggest the most likely diagnosis is osteosarcoma, which causes the characteristic periosteal reaction and radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance. Multiple myeloma often involves multiple bones, not just the hip. Chondrosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma have different radiographic features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiographic findings (radiolucent lesion with aggressive periosteal reaction) and photomicrograph suggest the most likely diagnosis is osteosarcoma. Multiple myeloma presents with lytic bone lesions that have small transition zones and no periosteal reaction. Chondrosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma may show cortical breakthrough, but not as extensive as seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiographic features and photomicrograph suggest that the most likely diagnosis is osteosarcoma, which typically presents as a radiolucent lesion with a periosteal reaction. Chondrosarcoma typically presents as a radiopaque lesion. Multiple myeloma typically presents with destructive lesions and is associated with hypercalcemia and plasma cell infiltration. Ewing sarcoma typically presents as a destructive lesion with an onion-skin periosteal reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiographic findings and photomicrograph suggest osteosarcoma. Multiple myeloma will show diffuse osteopenia but not a focal lesion. Chondrosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma do not typically cause a moth-eaten appearance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiographic appearance and the photomicrograph of the lesion suggest osteosarcoma. Multiple myeloma would present with lytic bone lesions but without the aggressive periosteal response seen here. Chondrosarcoma presents with a more homogeneous appearance and does not have the moth-eaten appearance seen here. Ewing sarcoma may show a similar radiographic appearance, but it is more commonly found in younger patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiolucent lesion with an aggressive periosteal reaction suggests osteosarcoma. Chondrosarcoma would have a more clearly defined border without periosteal reaction. Multiple myeloma would show diffuse osteoporosis without a periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma would have a permeative pattern of bone destruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiographic findings suggest an aggressive lesion with a wide transition zone and periosteal reaction, which is most consistent with osteosarcoma. The photomicrograph would likely show osteoid matrix formation by malignant osteoblasts. Multiple myeloma would not present with a radiolucent lesion with periosteal reaction. Chondrosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma are also rare but would have different characteristic radiographic findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows irregular bony trabeculae, suggestive of an osteoid- or bone-producing tumor. Among the options, only Osteosarcoma fits the description of a radiographically and histologically aggressive bone-forming tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The radiographic findings of a radiolucent lesion with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction are classic for osteosarcoma. None of the other options match these radiographic findings. The photomicrograph can also confirm the diagnosis of osteosarcoma.
